p: In order to understand apparent activation energy-conversion dependence, a plot of ln β as a function of 1/ T α obtained from DSC thermograms using various heating rates yields straight lines whose slope value is used to calculate the apparent activation energy ( Figure 7a). Then, the activation energies calculated were plotted as shown in Figure 7b as a function of conversion. It is seen that E α is highest at the beginning of curing, and then decreases with conversion throughout the entire curing process. The process of the curing reaction is autocatalytic because phenolic amine is an efficient hydrogen-bond donor molecule that promotes the ring opening of the epoxy group in the same way as the hydroxyl group of epoxy resin, leading to an auto-accelerating effect on the curing reaction and a decrease in apparent activation energy [ 31, 32]. In the initial stages of reaction, the generated hydroxyl groups are less and the catalytic effect is not obvious, thus the reaction activation energy is higher. As the reaction continues, the generated hydroxyl groups increase to promote the catalytic reaction effectively, the activation energy will be decreased. In addition, the temperature of the curing system increases and viscosity is reduced during the process of the curing reaction. These also accelerate the diffusion rate and reduce the activation energy [ 33].
